channel.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
channel.description:
[url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/09/23/switzerland.science/]http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/09/23/switzerland.science/[/url]
I don't know if many of you are physics enthusiasts, but this is remarkable and unbelievable even to a layman

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

[quote=“John459, post:65, topic:415681”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=517620.msg3762818#msg3762818 date=1316995532]

Now that that law has supposedly been proven wrong it opens up a lot of room for future scientific breakthroughs.
[/quote]Except it hasn’t been broken – at least not yet. It hasn’t even been tested. Besides, modern physics as we know it revolves around Einstein’s theory of relativity and it’s worked so far. To say that it’s simply wrong is fucking ridiculous. Even if this turns out to be factual and passes the trials, I’d be willing to bet it was a miscalculation of the speed of light, rather than claiming that Einstein’s whole theory is erroneous.

Well, modern physics excluding quantum physics revolves around Einstein’s theory of relativity.

Also, I doubt that the speed of light could have been miscalculated when you take into account the amount of times it probably has been calculated.[/quote]

Why not? I’m trying to dig up how they have the distance measured down exactly, since they must have accounted for errors in their calculations and a nanosecond goes down to a 10m error difference, so how they have been able to pin it exactly is a wonder of technology

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

Einsteins theories are exceptions themselves, aren’t they? So perhaps this won’t mean that Einsteins work is swept off the table, but just that there are exceptions.

Not quite exceptions; they modify the basic equations for relativity to incorporate the second postulate, that light is of constant speed regardless of reference frame.

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Frell:

I read warp speed was impossible in some article a few months ago, apparently youd be going so fast that youd hit so many particles at a speed that would rip you and your ship apart.

that may be the case but it doesn’t affect the show, warp engines work by creating a warp field in which the space outside of the field is distorted, the ship never actually moves when inside the warp field

oh and all of starfleet ships still have deflector shields for physical debris

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:63, topic:415681”][quote author=Newty link=topic=517620.msg3760266#msg3760266 date=1316809664]
Now that that law has supposedly been proven wrong it opens up a lot of room for future scientific breakthroughs.
[/quote]Except it hasn’t been broken – at least not yet. It hasn’t even been tested. Besides, modern physics as we know it revolves around Einstein’s theory of relativity and it’s worked so far. To say that it’s simply wrong is fucking ridiculous. Even if this turns out to be factual and passes the trials, I’d be willing to bet it was a miscalculation of the speed of light, rather than claiming that Einstein’s whole theory is erroneous.[/quote]

Well, modern physics excluding quantum physics revolves around Einstein’s theory of relativity.

Also, I doubt that the speed of light could have been miscalculated when you take into account the amount of times it probably has been calculated.

Read full topic

To say that it’s simply wrong is fucking ridiculous. Even if this turns out to be factual and passes the trials, I’d be willing to bet it was a miscalculation of the speed of light, rather than claiming that Einstein’s whole theory is erroneous.[/quote]

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:57, topic:415681”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=517620.msg3762405#msg3762405 date=1316973955]

Thats what I thought

So now the ultimate physics question, when you walk over an ant hill, are they really seeing your foot move in slow motion?

No, why should they do that, ants doesn’t have a velocity greater than 0.1c.
[/quote]
How come if you knock over a building its going slower than when you knock over a brick?[/quote]
Hmmm…
Time doesn’t go slower in normal speeds. For the velocity to have an effect by 10%, you need a speed on 0.4 c.
The reason that it is faster to knock down a brick is the distance.

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Although I find physics fascinating, I know jack shit about it. I know that time slows down when you come close to the speed of light, but I don’t know the mechanics behind it. Yesterday, a science journalist was a guest in a talk show (a good talk show, not Oprah like). He was talking about time going backwards when you go faster than light, which made me wonder. I don’t actually believe that you can go back to 1000 AD, because then you’d expect to be able to meet time travelers right now.

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Going back in time is pretty much impossible as far as current laws of physics are concerned.

Going into the future is possible, in layman’s terms, because time goes at different speeds in different places (mainly to do with the mass of the objects surrounding you).

Read full topic

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I was saying if going faster than the speed of light causes time to go in reverse, how does that play with the lives of organisms? Time is the 4th dimension, but it surely cant be as manipulable as a notebook… can it?

Read full topic

But thats assuming time is somehow being recorded

item.title: Particles travelling faster than LIGHT
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:47, topic:415681”][quote author=Frell link=topic=517620.msg3762283#msg3762283 date=1316969605]
Which means time travel is possible.

If a train goes around the earth traveling as close to the speed of light as possible, 10 minutes on the train will be 100 years outside of the train.
[/quote]

Apparently, if you go faster than light time actually ticks back. I was under the impression that only that which you described was possible, and going back to 1000 AD was impossible, but if you go faster than light you actually can go back to 1000 AD?[/quote]
The problem is that the time formula breaks down when you travel at the light of speed. So we can’t really be sure that is so easy.

t = t_0 / sqrt(1 - (v/c)^2)
Where t_0 is the time you experience when in movement, and t is the reference points time.
But if the velocity >= 1, the formula breaks down.

Read full topic
